answer_html: \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 2 3\\ 4 5 6\\ 7 8 9 \end{bmatrix}.\) The semicolon at the end of the line indicates that output is suppressed and so the matrix will not be displayed.For the second line of codeA(2,:)we recall that Matlab recognizes entries in a matrix first by row and column so a call A(i,j) would return an element in row i and column j. The colon instructs Matlab to take all the entries of a given field. Therefore A(:,j) instructs Matlab to output all entries in column j while A(i,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries in row i. Therefore A(2,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries from row 2.If we look at out matrix then the output would be[4  5  6]Notice the lack of semicolon on this output indicates that the output is not suppressed.
answer_latex:
$A=\begin{bmatrix}
1    2    3\\
4    5    6\\
7    8    9
\end{bmatrix}.$ The semicolon at the end of the line indicates that output is suppressed
and so the matrix will not be displayed.For the second line of code\texttt{A(2,:)}we recall that Matlab recognizes entries in a matrix first by row and
column so a call A(i,j) would return an element in row i and column j.
The colon instructs Matlab to take all the entries of a given field.
Therefore A(:,j) instructs Matlab to output all entries in column j
while A(i,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries in row i.
Therefore A(2,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries from row
2.If we look at out matrix then the output would be\texttt{{[}4~~5~~6{]}}Notice the lack of semicolon on this output indicates that the output is
\textbf{not} suppressed.
hints_html: What is the difference between a space and a semicolon when defining a matrix. What does the colon do?
hints_latex:
What is the difference between a space and a semicolon when defining a
matrix. What does the colon do?
hints_raw: What is the difference between a space and a semicolon when defining a matrix.  What does the colon do?
question: A 06
sols_html:
For the first line of code

A=[1 2 3;4 5 6;7 8 9];

we recall that when declaring a matrix in Matlab, square brackets [ and ] start and end the declaration. While inside a space indicates to move to the next column while a semicolon instructs to start a new row. Therefore we place the entries 1, 2, and 3 in the three columns of the first row; 4, 5, and 6 in the three columns of the second row and 7, 8, and 9 in the three columns of the last row. Therefore the matrix generated is

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3\\ 4 & 5 & 6\\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

The semicolon at the end of the line indicates that output is suppressed and so the matrix will not be displayed. For the second line of code

A(2,:)

we recall that Matlab recognizes entries in a matrix first by row and column so a call A(i,j) would return an element in row i and column j. The colon instructs Matlab to take all the entries of a given field. Therefore A(:,j) instructs Matlab to output all entries in column j while A(i,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries in row i. Therefore A(2,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries from row 2. If we look at out matrix then the output would be

[4  5  6]

Notice the lack of semicolon on this output indicates that the output is not suppressed.
sols_latex:
For the first line of code

\texttt{A={[}1~2~3;4~5~6;7~8~9{]};}

we recall that when declaring a matrix in Matlab, square brackets {[}
and {]} start and end the declaration. While inside a space indicates to
move to the next column while a semicolon instructs to start a new row.
Therefore we place the entries 1, 2, and 3 in the three columns of the
first row; 4, 5, and 6 in the three columns of the second row and 7, 8,
and 9 in the three columns of the last row. Therefore the matrix
generated is

\begin{align*}
A=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  2  &  3\\
4  &  5  &  6\\
7  &  8  &  9
\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align*}

The semicolon at the end of the line indicates that output is suppressed
and so the matrix will not be displayed. For the second line of code

\texttt{A(2,:)}

we recall that Matlab recognizes entries in a matrix first by row and
column so a call A(i,j) would return an element in row i and column j.
The colon instructs Matlab to take all the entries of a given field.
Therefore A(:,j) instructs Matlab to output all entries in column j
while A(i,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries in row i.
Therefore A(2,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries from row
2. If we look at out matrix then the output would be

\texttt{{[}4~~5~~6{]}}

Notice the lack of semicolon on this output indicates that the output is
\textbf{not} suppressed.
sols_raw:
For the first line of code

 A=[1 2 3;4 5 6;7 8 9];

we recall that when declaring a matrix in Matlab, square brackets [ and ] start and end the declaration.  While inside a space indicates to move to the next column while a semicolon instructs to start a new row.  Therefore we place the entries 1, 2, and 3 in the three columns of the first row; 4, 5, and 6 in the three columns of the second row and 7, 8, and 9 in the three columns of the last row.  Therefore the matrix generated is

:<math>
A=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  2  &  3\\
4  &  5  &  6\\
7  &  8  &  9
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

The semicolon at the end of the line indicates that output is suppressed and so the matrix will not be displayed.  For the second line of code

 A(2,:)

we recall that Matlab recognizes entries in a matrix first by row and column so a call A(i,j) would return an element in row i and column j.  The colon instructs Matlab to take all the entries of a given field.  Therefore A(:,j) instructs Matlab to output all entries in column j while A(i,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries in row i.  Therefore A(2,:) instructs Matlab to output all of the entries from row 2.  If we look at out matrix then the output would be

 [4  5  6]

Notice the lack of semicolon on this output indicates that the output is '''not''' suppressed.
statement_html:
What is the output after the following lines of MATLAB code?

A = [1 2 3; 4 5 6; 7 8 9];
A(2,:)
statement_latex:
What is the output after the following lines of MATLAB code?

\texttt{A~=~{[}1~2~3;~4~5~6;~7~8~9{]};}\\\texttt{A(2,:)}
